plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial herbaceous plant cherished for its winter blooms. It produces large, white to pale pink, cup-shaped flowers often appearing in mid-winter, including December. It thrives in shaded garden areas of Europe and parts of North America.
plants.location: Central and Southern Europe, cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose; its flowers can bloom even through snow.

plants.name: Prunus mume
plants.description: A deciduous tree that begins to flower in late winter and sometimes as early as December. It produces fragrant pink or white blossoms which are treasured in East Asian cultures, marking the onset of spring even in colder months.
plants.funFact: Prunus mume blossoms are celebrated in Japanese and Chinese art and poetry for their beauty and early bloom.

plants.name: Calothamnus quadrifidus
plants.description: An Australian native shrub with bright red, bottlebrush-like flowers that bloom in late spring and sporadically throughout the year, including December. Its vibrant blooms attract birds and pollinators in the wild.
plants.funFact: The flowers have four claw-like stamen bundles, giving the plant its species name 'quadrifidus', meaning 'split into four'.

plants.name: Euphorbia pulcherrima
plants.description: An iconic winter-flowering plant widely cultivated for its brilliant red and green foliage, popular during the Christmas season. The colored bracts are often mistaken for petals and surround small yellow flowers.
plants.location: Native to Central America; widely grown worldwide as a holiday plant
plants.funFact: The poinsettia is named after Joel Roberts Poinsett, the first U.S. Minister to Mexico, who introduced the plant to the United States in the 1820s.
